PREVENTION PROGRAM DESCRIPTION

Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program

The Prevention program consists of the following elements:

7 Employee Participation: This program involves the employees in establishing and implementing the program.  Employees are also involved when a process hazard analysis is conducted.  The program also ensures that all employees have complete access to the program.
7 Process Safety Information: Written information has been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the systems.  The written information includes the ammonia MSDS and a description of the design of the ammonia systems.
7 Process Hazard Analysis: Formal studies using the What-If Technique have been conducted to look at the systems and identify potential hazards.
7 Operating Procedures: Written operating procedures have been developed which describe the steps, which should be followed to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration systems.
7 Training:  A training program has been developed which ensures that employees are trained on all aspects of the systems and on the duties, which they should perform to ensure the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration systems.
7 Contractors:  All contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration systems.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they perform work by following safe work practices.
7 Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup safety review is completed for all new ammonia projects to verify that all safety programs are in place, training has been performed, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the project is put to use.
7 Mechanical Integrity: This program ensures that the ammonia refrigeration systems are built and maintained using preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.
7 Hot Work Permit: The procedures ensure that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning.
7 Management of Change: The procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the ammonia refrigeration systems are properly reviewed.
7 Incident Investigation: The Procedures ensure that any incidents (and near misses) are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an investigation team.
7 Compliance Audits: There are procedures to conduct regular audits of the program to ensure the program is in place and working properly.

RISK MANAGEMENT  PLAN [40 CFR PART 68, SUBPART G/CALARP ARTICLE 3]

EXECUTIVE SUMARY [40 CFR 68.155/CALRP 2745.3]

RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Growers Ice Company facility utilizes inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment installation and startup of all equipment prior to startup.  These procedures identify potential sources of release and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases.  The equipment is reviewed by onsite personnel, registered engineers, and certified refrigeration contractors as required.

Initial emergency response is provided by onsite personnel.  Onsite personnel will make a preliminary assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response.  First response may include emergency equipment shutdown, system isolation, or controlled operation such as pump down to prevent or reduce an off-site release.  Emergency response for a major release event will be provided by local fire and police departments with mutual aide response.

Emergency response training will be conducted yearly and as required for new employees.  Records will be kept of all training performed at the site for a minimum of five (5) years.

All ammonia refrigeration maintenance and operations personnel are required to be trained and become familiar with the company' Safety and Operations Procedures and Emergency Response Plan.  Maintenance and operations personnel will also be required to become familiar with the RMP.

DESCRIPTION OF SOURCE AND SUBSTANCE HANDLED

The Growers Ice Company facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia in the produce and cold storage operations.

Produce is brought to the facility where it is pre-cooled and stored for processing and shipment.  Produce includes a variety of lettuce, cabbage, broccoli, strawberries, and salad products.

Anhydrous ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the cooling system.  Following on-site pre-cooling, cooled products are stored in a number of different cold storage

rooms.  The cold room/dock system, which consists of 18 cold rooms, 3 refrigerated shipping docks, 2 refrigerated ice storage rooms and 7 pressure cooler rooms provide for general cold storage and pre-cooling of produce.

In addition to the cold rooms, docks and pressure cooler rooms there are 2 permanent Vacuum cooler tubes, 2 Hydro-cooler units and 4 Block Ice manufacturing tanks.  There can be as many as 7 portable Ice Generators connected to the refrigeration system, as many as 6 portable Hydro-vac units, and as many as 4 self-contained Ice Generator trailers on site during the months of April through November.

A permanent compressor room provides refrigeration, with 10 compressors with 10 condenser units and 2 on-line liquid receivers and 1 off line receiver.  The engine room is supplemented by as many as 3 portable high-side (compressor/condenser) trailers that can be connected to the refrigeration system.

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

An offsite consequence analysis for an ammonia release was performed.  The release parameters are in section 2.  The worst case scenario had a toxic endpoint at 18,600 ft.  The residential population affected by this worse case release is estimated to be 21,507.

WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The worst case and alternate release scenarios were evaluated using the methodologies recommended in the RMP Off-site Consequence Analysis Guidance as prepared by the EPA.  As a part of this guidance a Model Risk Management Program and Plan for Ammonia Refrigeration was prepared to identify specific release scenarios for ammonia based refrigeration systems.  The atmospheric conditions used are as specified in the regulations and the guide.

The Worst Case Release considers the complete release of the maximum charge in any individual system within a 10-minute period.  The High Pressure Receiver has the largest quantity of ammonia and is considered for this scenario.  It contains a potential maximum liquid quantity of 20,000 g

allons of ammonia during a three-month period in the winter season.  This system is considered the Worst Case scenario.

 The alternate release considers the release of low-pressure liquid ammonia from a flange or connection leak on the rooftop piping system.  No mitigation measures are considered for each release.  Administrative controls limit the maximum amount of refrigerant in each system.

The results of the Worst case and alternate case scenarios are presented in section 3.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

As described above, the program consists of a pre-startup inspection, emergency response, and regular training.  A thorough review of the system including a Hazop analysis was performed prior to startup for 1999 season.  Equipment corrections and updates were made for those items determined to have the highest potential for off-site releases.  Safety and equipment operational training will be conducted on a yearly basis and will include equipment operational procedures, emergency response procedures, review of Business Response Procedures, and evacuation procedures.  Those items requiring further review, correction, and/or updating are listed in the RMP- Correction Items.
Refrigeration equipment will be reviewed as required.  Updates when changes to equipment occur or when new equipment is brought on-site.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No reportable releases or accidents relating to the release of ammonia refrigerant have occurred at the facility in the last five years.

EMMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has implemented the State and County mandated emergency response plan (a.k.a. Business Response Plan).  This plan outlines procedures for emergency ammonia release as well as general facility response.

PLANNED SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS

Safety improvements have been identified during the preparation of this program.  These improvements have been documented and a schedule developed for their implementation.  Some of the improvements include installa
tion of seismic restrains, change out of the pressure relief valves 5 years old or older, and development of operational procedures
